item.title: A Marvellous Light
item.description: Fun Edwardian murder mystery. Fun world building. God save Edwin from the idiotic flower of English manhood.

item.title: A Wizard of Earthsea
item.description: This felt like something between prologue and parable, and yet I’m still into it. More Earthsea, here I come.

item.title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi
item.description: A rollicking pirate adventure AND an extensive bibliography for the historical accuracies! Be still my heart! This was brilliant. It would be easier to make a list of the things I didn’t like about it than all the things I loved.

item.title: The Sorcerer of the Wildeeps
item.description: Whoa. Masterful use of dialect and structure to deconstruct the traditional bounds of genre and narrative. The way the characters code-switch their way through multiple registers and languages—well-known and invented—is reflected in the way the novella flips through genres like a catalog, exposing the expectations and limitations of each.

item.title: A Restless Truth
item.description: This was so close to being great. SO CLOSE. But overall, the book felt kind of like the menagerie on board the ship, let loose in all directions, refusing to be corralled.

item.title: The Tombs of Atuan
item.description: The funny thing is, I sometimes resist reading Ursula K. Le Guin. Because I know I’ll have to stop, and do nothing else, and absorb through my pores, and not read any of the other ten or twelve things I might have read that week, and just camp out in her world as long as I can.

item.title: A Power Unbound
item.description: Here is my theory from [[books/a restless truth|book 2]]: the Blyths suit me best in small doses. Robin and Maud, respectively, were the most difficult parts of their own books for me.

item.title: Among Others
item.description: “[[notes/bibliotropic|Bibliotropic]],” Hugh said. “Like sunflowers are heliotropic, they naturally turn towards the sun. We naturally turn towards the bookshop.”

item.title: Aspects
item.description: The poignancy of having this one cut off, incomplete. What a feat it would have been. What a feat it still is.

item.title: Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch
item.description: Historical (fan)fiction of Katarina Kepler, Johannes Kepler’s mother, famously tried as a witch. It’s fantastic, the character work, the structure, the narrative voice(s), the exuberant black humor that becomes blacker and blacker as it follows the warp of history.

item.title: Three Kings
item.description: Another for my collection of killer opening lines: Ethan Shaw carried two knives, one for lilies, the other for veins.
